data.title: 'Do the Right Thing,' 'New Jack City' actor Bill Nunn dies at 62
data.meta_description: The star's wife announced the news yesterday and said that Nunn died in his home.
data.text:
Obit Bill Nunn

FILE - This May 3, 2008 file photo shows actor Bill Nunn, right, at a Point Park University rehearsal for his experimental project, dramatizing an African folktale, in Pittsburgh. Nunn, a veteran character actor whose credits ranged from the "Spider-Man" movie franchise to such Spike Lee films as "Do the Right Thing" and "He Got Game," has died. His wife, Donna, said Nunn died Saturday, Sept. 24, 2016 at his home in Pittsburgh. (AP Photo/Keith Srakocic, file)

(Keith Srakocic)

Actor Bill Nunn, known for his role in "Do the Right Thing" and "New Jack City" has died.

He was 62.

Nunn's wife Donna announced the news on Saturday, and said that the actor died at his Pittsburgh home.

The character actor had many roles in his career, most notably in the "Spider-Man" franchise, "He Got Game," and "Sister Act."

Nunn's first role was in 1988's "School Daze," when he was cast by Spike Lee. Lee posted a photo of Nunn on Instagram yesterday, and referred to Nunn as his "dear friend."

"Long Live Bill Nunn. Radio Raheem is now resting in power. Radio Raheem will always be fighting da powers dat be. May God Watch over Bill Nunn," he posted.

Nunn played the role of Radio Raheem in "Do the Right Thing," one of Lee's films.

According to Rolling Stone, Nunn discovered his love of acting at Morehouse College after majoring in English.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.
